conversation.content: [excited] They're calling me up for the award, the—the National Activist of the Year, can you believe it? [pause] God, I worked so hard for this, like, fifteen years of campaigns and protests and [proudly] changing actual laws. [short pause] Sarah should be here. [sad] She was supposed to—but we haven't talked since, um, since I missed her birthday for that conference. [regretful] Third birthday in a row, actually. [clearing throat] And Mom called yesterday, said she doesn't even recognize me anymore, [bitter] said I care more about strangers than my own family. [defensive] That's not—I mean, someone has to fight for these causes, right? [shaky voice] The kids I'm helping, they need someone who won't give up, who'll [passionately] dedicate everything to making change happen. [quietly] Everything. [long pause] Jake moved out last week. [crying while speaking] Said he couldn't compete with my mission anymore, said he felt like—like a ghost in his own home. [sniffle] They're announcing my name now, everyone's clapping, and I'm supposed to feel [hesitantly] proud? Accomplished? [very sad] I've saved so many families, but I couldn't save my own. [exhausted] How's that for irony?
